repnme.cdata!: Albania - Municipal Water and Wastewater Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Municipal Water and
            Wastewater Project for Albania were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            investment budgets under management contracts should be
            sufficient in relation to existing needs if they are to have
            an impact on the quality of service in line with
            expectations of the clients. Risks associated with staffing
            reductions need to be highlighted upfront in project
            appraisal documents (PADs), especially where project
            outcomes are partly dependent on the reductions. Moreover,
            where such reductions are recommended in a project, staff
            should be recognized as key stakeholders and their concerns
            considered in the social analysis. The quality of the
            operator's individual staff is of paramount importance
            to the success of management contracts. While originally
            offered staff appeared to possess the required
            qualifications, the operator changed the expatriate staff of
            its management team three times. The frequent changes
            increased the difficulties of operator staff to become
            knowledgeable of the systems and of the sector governance
            and in the end reduced their effectiveness.

repnme.cdata!: Albania - Municipal Water and Wastewater Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall development objective of the
            Municipal Water and Wastewater Project for Albania is to
            improve water supply and sanitation services in four
            participating cities and achieve financial viability in
            their water utilities, by introducing a new incentive-based
            multi-city management contract approach. There are three
            project components. The first finances the costs related to
            the five-year management contract. These costs include a
            base fee and a performance-based fee to be paid to the
            Operator according to the achievement of targets defined in
            the contract. The Operator will be given full responsibility
            for managing the investment program; operating the water
            supply and sewerage systems; developing and implementing the
            demand management program, including a public awareness
            campaign; and implementing improved commercial (billing and
            collection) and financial management system. The second
            component, the Investment Fund, finances works, goods, and
            services aimed at improving the operation of the water
            supply and sanitation services, and achieving the
            performance targets in the management contract. The third
            component strengthens project implementation by supporting
            the Project Implementation Unit, including salaries,
            training, vehicles, and incremental operating costs; and
            various consulting services for supervision of the
            management contract and audits, studies, and field
            investigations related to the Project.

docna.cdata!: Albania - Municipal Water and Wastewater Project

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Municipal Water and Wastewater
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental management plan
            framework (EMPF) ensures that the Municipal Water and
            Wastewater Project in Albania is implemented in accordance
            with the Bank operational guidelines, and the country's
            environmental laws and regulations. However, these legal
            provisions have not been systematically implemented in the
            country, neither has a detailed legislation been enacted,
            though under the 1993 Law, environmental impact assessment
            is a pollution control instrument, as well as a development
            planning instrument, currently being revised in a European
            Union assisted project. Thus, environmental indicators will
            be monitored annually, in accordance with the Law, and, Bank
            operational guidelines will be included in the contract with
            the private operator. Impacts, and its mitigation measures
            are as follows. Rehabilitation of water production
            facilities, and distribution networks will induce soil, and
            water contamination by water treatment sludge, including
            groundwater pollution due to construction run-offs, improper
            waste disposal, and/or spillage of fuel and oil, while
            vegetation will be degraded: waste disposal sites will be
            selected, and drainage and runoffs controlled, including
            performance of bacteriological, and chemical tests, while
            oil spillage will be stored in tank/drums, and vegetative
            propagation enforced. Noise disturbances will be abated by
            limiting working schedules to daylight hours only, while
            noise suppression devices will be installed in construction
            equipment. Dust pollution will be suppressed through water
            sprinkling, and removal of excess material. Traffic
            increases will have to be re-routed in coordination with
            local authorities, and standard safety measures.

docna.cdata!:
Albania - Municipal Water and Wastewater
            Project : environmental assessment
